meaning: The word 'also' is used to indicate that something is in addition to what has already been mentioned. It serves to add information or to emphasize a point.
etymology: The word 'also' originates from the Old English word 'eallswā', which means 'just as, even so, likewise'. It is a combination of 'eall' (all) and 'swā' (so). Over time, it evolved into the Middle English 'alswa' and eventually into the modern English 'also'.
sentence: She is not only a great singer but also an accomplished dancer.
He also mentioned that he would be late.
As Shakespeare wrote, 'To thine own self be true, and it must follow, as the night the day, thou canst not then be false to any man.' Also, 'This above all: to thine own self be true.'
short_stories: In a small village, there was a wise old man who always said, 'Knowledge is important, but wisdom is also crucial.' One day, a young boy asked him why. The old man replied, 'Because knowledge tells you how to do things, but wisdom tells you whether you should do them.'
A farmer once said to his son, 'Hard work is important, but rest is also necessary.' The son learned that balance is key to a happy life.
poetry: In 'The Road Not Taken' by Robert Frost, the poet writes, 'Two roads diverged in a wood, and I— / I took the one less traveled by, / And that has made all the difference.' The word 'also' is implied in the contemplation of choices.

In 'If' by Rudyard Kipling, the poet writes, 'If you can meet with Triumph and Disaster / And treat those two impostors just the same;' The word 'also' is implied in the balanced treatment of both success and failure.
